📄 NCEA Guide for Teens What is NCEA? NCEA stands for National Certificate of Educational Achievement, the main qualification for Year 11-13 students in Aotearoa (NZ). It's made up of three levels:
  • Level 1 - Year 11
  • Level 2 - Year 12
  • Level 3 - Year 13
Each level requires 80 credits to be achieved. 2. How Do You Earn Credits Credits are earned by doing assessments called standards:
  • Achievement Standards: graded N, A, M, or E
  • Unit Standards: graded A or N
Each standard is worth a set number of credits-add them up to earn your Level. 3. Literacy & Numeracy Credits To complete Level 1, you must have:
  • 10 Literacy credits
  • 10 Numeracy credits
Literacy credits can be earned through English or other subjects that assess reading/writing skills. Numeracy credits can be earned through Maths or subjects that assess numerical skills. New Co-Req Standards (Introduced 2024)
  • Separate tests for:
  • Reading
  • Writing
  • Numeracy
You must pass all three. If needed, you can re-sit these tests multiple times, even after Year 11. 4. Internal vs External Assessments
  • Internal assessments: done during the school year (ex: projects, essays).
  • External assessments: exams or tasks at year's end, marked by NZQA.

5. Endorsements (for high achievement) A. Certificate Endorsements
  • Merit: gain 50 credits at Merit
  • Excellence: gain 50 credits at Excellence
B. Course Endorsements (per subject)
  • 14 credits at Merit or Excellence
  • Must include:
  • At least 3 internal
  • At least 3 external

Image found on the NCEA Grammar guide

6. What Do the Levels Mean?

  • Level 1 requires 80 credits from any level Literacy and Numeracy: Includes 10 literacy + 10 numeracy.
  • Level 2 requires 80 credits, 60 of which from Level 2+ (20 carried over) Literacy/numeracy is from Level 1.
  • Level 3 requires 80 credits 60 of which from Level 3+, Literacy/numeracy from is again from Level 1.
7. Getting Started In March, your school sends your entries to NZQA You become an official NCEA candidate Track results via the NZQA Learner Portal 8. Why NCEA Matters Needed for uni, jobs, apprenticeships Recognised in New Zealand and internationally Shows your learning achievements and strengths 9. Quick Tips for Teens Choose subjects that give credits you need Mix internal & external credits to aim for course endorsements Check your portal often to track progress Start literacy/numeracy early so you're ready Ask for help from your teachers anytime
